alert.note: Alert for Los Angeles (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued January 09 at 11:51PM PST until January 10 at 1:30AM PST by NWS Oxnard
info.description: The National Weather Service in Los Angeles/Oxnard has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... The Fish and much of Bobcat burn scar in... East Central Los Angeles County in southwestern California... * Until 130 AM PST. * At 1151 PM PST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain falling over the Fish and much of Bobcat Burn Scar. Between 2 and 5 inches of rain have fallen. Rainfall rates of 0.5 to 1 inch per hour are expected. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected in the warned area. Life threatening debris flows are expected. HAZARD...Life threatening debris flows in and around the Fish and much of Bobcat Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges. IMPACT...Mud, rock, and debris flows will impact drainages, roads, and residences in and directly below the burn area. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Acton, Mount Wilson, Glendora, Pasadena, San Dimas, Pomona, La Verne, Angeles Crest Highway between Mount Wilson and Mount Waterman, Monrovia, Falling Springs, Sierra Madre, Azusa, Arcadia, Angeles Crest Highway between Mount Waterman and Wrightwood, Covina, Claremont, Duarte and Irwindale, and the Fish and much of the Bobcat burn areas. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR AND GAUGE INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...0.5-1 INCH IN 1 HOUR
info.instruction: A Flash Flood Warning for a recent burn area means that flooding and debris flows are imminent or occurring. Residents living in or immediately downstream should take immediate precautions to protect life and property. Quickly move away from the burn area only if it is safe to do so, otherwise shelter in place and move to a second story or the highest location in your home to stay out of the path of fast-moving water and debris flows. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
